1.brief: a brother (used in the widest sense of literal relationship and metaphorical affinity or resemblance (like father))
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
a sister (used very widely (like brother), literally and figuratively)
to fondle; by implication, to love, especially to compassionate

2.brief: properly, to toss, i.e. grapple; mostly figuratively, to wrangle, i.e. hold a controversy; (by implication) to defend
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
properly, to toss, i.e. grapple; mostly figuratively, to wrangle, i.e. hold a controversy; (by implication) to defend
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
between (repeated before each noun, often with other particles); also as a conjunction, either...or
the breast of a woman or animal (as bulging)

3.brief: properly, removal; used only (in the construction) adverb as conjunction, lest
to spread out (i.e. deploy in hostile array); by analogy, to strip (i.e. unclothe, plunder, flay, etc.)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
to bear young; causatively, to beget; medically, to act as midwife; specifically, to show lineage
to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)
a pasture (i.e. open field, whither cattle are driven); by implication, a desert; also speech (including its organs)
to place (in a very wide application)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to die (literally or figuratively); causatively, to kill

4.brief: properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to fondle; by implication, to love, especially to compassionate

a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
to be ashamed, confused or disappointed; also (as failing) to dry up (as water) or wither (as herbage)
to be (or become) pregnant, conceive (literally or figuratively)
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
properly, the hind part; generally used as an adverb or conjunction, after (in various senses)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)
water; figuratively, juice; by euphemism, urine, semen
grease, especially liquid (as from the olive, often perfumed); figuratively, richness

to entwine, i.e. shut in (for formation, protection or restraint)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
a pot; also a thorn (as springing up rapidly); by implication, a hook

not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

at that time or place; also as a conjunction, therefore
at this time, whether adverb, conjunction or expletive
